5.23.23  4:23 am   Why does my composition teacher say that music written in sharp keys sound brighter and music written in flat keys sound darker? Surely because intervals are all relative, the absolute pitch around which the piece revolves doesn't matter?

      it doesn't matter unless you change keys in the middle. and if you change by more than 6 degrees, it will actually sound like you went the other way around

5.22.23  8:51 pm   I know everyone has a different path of learning how to make music, but what do you think are the bare bones "music theory" (I don't like that phrase, I prefer to call it "music terminology") essentials for a beginner?

     maybe it would be cool to find some kind of piano keyboard and start playing with it

     I think knowing the names of the notes ( just knowing what notes you're playing) and knowing basic chord names are really the most important things.

     that would be useful for communicating with other musicians

     I was thinking maybe understanding key signatures, but I think you can probably write a chord patte rn/melody without fully understanding what key you're in or that this chord is the IV or that chord is the vii or whatever..

     i'd personally like to ditch the roman numerals. they're just numbers, and i think the roman is much harder to read. i prefer arabic numberals instead (1, 2, 3, 4). also sometimes called "nashville numbers"

     although that would probably be the next thing to learn after basic note names/chord names. Maybe understanding rhythmic counting?

     yes, that is definitely good

     But I feel like if you have a good feel/timing you can probably get by without knowing all the rhythmic terminology and how all that stuff works.

Learning to read notation, I think opens up more gig opportunities if you're a working, professional musician... Buts lots of musicians don't know how to read music, so I don't think that's essential for a beginner.

I was thinking about getting into teaching, but I started so young that I have very little recollection of first learning.

     teaching might be very frustrating for you

     By the time I started piano lessons as a kid, I was already self taught to the point that I had developed enough feel to play simple stuff by ear.

     yes, teaching will be very frustrating for you. except for that one student who is already a self-learner, who you will love, who also won't even need your help

     And lessons for me were more learning the terminology, scales, chord names, key signatures, reading notation, etc. But even with that, I was like 4 or 5 years old and I don't really remember much specifics from my very early lessons.

5.22.23  12:02 am   It sort of feels like to me that music recording was supposed to be (in some greater philosophical sense) what it was in the 60s/70s. Just run through the thing as needed, make it a high quality recording, but don't spend too much time on it. Maybe digital technology wasn't the greatest thing for music. What do you think about this? I've heard you express some jealousy for the situation they had back then

      each time period has its own qualities. if you go back to 1900, there is another interesting quality: no copies. so every record sold is a different take
